turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I have a big interview coming up for a project manager role. I'm feeling pretty overwhelmed. Can you help me prepare?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Certainly! I can assist you with preparing for your project manager interview. We can cover common interview questions, behavioral questions, technical questions related to project management, and even practice your responses. Where would you like to start?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Ugh, behavioral questions always get me. Can we focus on those? Like, 'Tell me about a time you failed' - I always blank!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, let's tackle behavioral questions. A good approach to answering 'Tell me about a time you failed' is using the STAR method: Situation, Task, Action, Result. Can you think of a project where, in hindsight, something didn't go as planned? Don't focus on huge disasters, even minor setbacks can work.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hmm, okay, there was this one time where the project scope kept creeping and I didn't push back enough. The team got burned out and we went over budget. But how do I spin that into something positive without sounding completely incompetent? That's the part I struggle with!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid concern. Frame it as a learning experience. You can say something like, '...As a result of this experience, I learned the importance of proactively managing scope creep. Now, I implement stricter change control processes and communicate scope limitations more effectively to stakeholders. I also prioritize regular check-ins with the team to identify potential burnout early on.' Does that help?
